text: Thanks :) It was a lot of fun to create and put together. My learned lesson was to not make the book too long that delegates don’t read it at the conference. After all, they are there to mix and mingle. So many have told me they were planning on reading it on the plane home. So if you were to do something similar, be sure to add a call to action in the book.

text:
Would love some feedback on this: <https://dispatch.m.io/unified-comms-influencers/>
We made it last year and plan to update this year.
Results-wise, it couldn't have been better. 80% have guest posted for us, promoted for free on social, lean on us for quotes. I've even started a spin-off podcast.
But I know we can make it a lot better.

text: I agree with comments made above! We're focusing a lot more on influencer content and outreach. I've also heard that Reddit is a great space too (haven't had the opportunity to explore it myself). A lot of our most successful marketing though happens when we work with our partners. We're a Shopify app so can easily work with other companies in our ecosystem. We've done ebooks, webinars and guest blogs with them and it's always a great opportunity to promote our own content to a new and relevant audience.

text: These are all really good ideas! Not revolutionary, but we've combined the idea of using influencers with webinars and podcasts. We use a content piece like an article as a guide to the webinar/podcast. We've also had a lot of fun with using content pieces in direct mail kits. They often need repurposed, like that amazing comic book idea from Dan, but I've seen some success with that.

text: For those of you who work with/manage their content teams whether in-house or freelance: what questions do you’ve about about giving feedback on content? Asking for a piece that I’m doing. My goal is to understand exactly what troubles you with giving feedback to writers. Thanks!

elements.text: For those of you who work with/manage their content teams whether in-house or freelance: what questions do you’ve about about giving feedback on content? Asking for a piece that I’m doing. My goal is to understand exactly what troubles you with giving feedback to writers. Thanks!

text: I seem to give the same feedback over and over again. How do I make it stick?

elements.text: I seem to give the same feedback over and over again. How do I make it stick?

text: <@U012R27LRJ8> when it comes to SEO, both actually. Having 100 experts on a topic in one article makes for a very long read, which could be fine, but organizing that in way that it makes sense to users is the hard bit (which also takes most time and most neglect). You’d have to add categorization for the list to make sense.

elements.text: when it comes to SEO, both actually. Having 100 experts on a topic in one article makes for a very long read, which could be fine, but organizing that in way that it makes sense to users is the hard bit (which also takes most time and most neglect). You’d have to add categorization for the list to make sense.

text: I find myself grappling with "How do I protect my writers from getting multiple, even contradictory feedback, from various approvers?" Some companies I work for have been good about respecting the process and are more than happy to give me full feedback/approval power. Other companies/teams haven't been good about that.

elements.text: I find myself grappling with "How do I protect my writers from getting multiple, even contradictory feedback, from various approvers?" Some companies I work for have been good about respecting the process and are more than happy to give me full feedback/approval power. Other companies/teams haven't been good about that.

text: The multiple approval process is one I have a particular distaste for. Especially, if it's just content. I.e. the content manager reviews and gives feedback then an editor does the same. 99% of the time they contradict each other.

elements.text: The multiple approval process is one I have a particular distaste for. Especially, if it's just content. I.e. the content manager reviews and gives feedback then an editor does the same. 99% of the time they contradict each other.

text: i think the answer is really different depending on whether you’re working with in-house or freelance writers. in my experience, it’s easier to build rapport with an in-house team and that’s super important for the writers to feel like the feedback is an investment in their development.

elements.text: i think the answer is really different depending on whether you’re working with in-house or freelance writers. in my experience, it’s easier to build rapport with an in-house team and that’s super important for the writers to feel like the feedback is an investment in their development.

text: for freelancers, the relationship is often more transactional and rounds of feedback may need to be built into their contract

elements.text: for freelancers, the relationship is often more transactional and rounds of feedback may need to be built into their contract

text: <@UJJFDTN8G> It's maddening! Especially because I always allow for feedback from the appropriate people (SMEs, editors, etc.). It happens most often and becomes so confusing for writers when the feedback is given as a result in a change of strategy, which is a larger business issue. Or when you have a rogue VP or CMO who kind of pops in-and-out of certain projects. Which is certainly their prerogative, but isn't always helpful.

text: The multiple approver thing is so difficult. A framework I’ve seen be helpful: after-the-fact edits vs in-progress edits. For all but the most important content efforts, communicate that you will gladly take feedback from execs AFTER something is published (and mean it! gladly!). That helps you calibrate over the long term without disrupting your teams ability to ship.

elements.text: The multiple approver thing is so difficult. A framework I’ve seen be helpful: after-the-fact edits vs in-progress edits. For all but the most important content efforts, communicate that you will gladly take feedback from execs AFTER something is published (and mean it! gladly!). That helps you calibrate over the long term without disrupting your teams ability to ship.

text: also: sometimes the exec is wrong! And it’s helpful to have performance metrics to ground any after-the-fact feedback.

elements.text: also: sometimes the exec is wrong! And it’s helpful to have performance metrics to ground any after-the-fact feedback.

text: <@UJJFDTN8G> is this repeat feedback for one writer or several writers?

elements.text: is this repeat feedback for one writer or several writers?

text:
with freelancers, every round of revisions costs time and money (for both parties).

that puts lots of pressure on an initial revision to catch as many things as possible. requests for multiple revisions, at the very least, weaken relationships (i.e. piss off freelancers); some freelancers also charge for more than one revision.

that pressure definitely refines editing skills and helps build out processes that extend back to the initial pitch and outline to get as aligned as possible as early as possible.

but it's still suboptimal. at times, i find myself giving almost hypothetical feedback (e.g., "not sure if you're thinking of it this way..." or "if you end up going down this route instead of that one...") that probably adds more noise than signal, but the fear is "if i don't include it now, it could be tougher to bring up later."

elements.text:
with freelancers, every round of revisions costs time and money (for both parties).

that puts lots of pressure on an initial revision to catch as many things as possible. requests for multiple revisions, at the very least, weaken relationships (i.e. piss off freelancers); some freelancers also charge for more than one revision.

that pressure definitely refines editing skills and helps build out processes that extend back to the initial pitch and outline to get as aligned as possible as early as possible.

but it's still suboptimal. at times, i find myself giving almost hypothetical feedback (e.g., "not sure if you're thinking of it this way..." or "if you end up going down this route instead of that one...") that probably adds more noise than signal, but the fear is "if i don't include it now, it could be tougher to bring up later."

text: <@UJJFDTN8G> Re: your united comms piece, you could add a section to some of the blocks that say something like "See Paul's work at <http://example.com|example.com>" and link to another platform (e.g. blog, podcast) they're affiliated with. Then let those platforms know you've linked to them. Could be a nice way to build relationships with platforms in your space

text:
How would you approach determining your position’s worth at your employer?

I was recently asked by my manager to “come up with a dollar amount” on the value of my position. I’m assured this isn’t some sideways test — we’re trying to come up with a budget for hiring additional content staff.

I’m a content director, running the content strategy process for a small SEO agency in California.

I’m happy with my salary, which is my reference point. But I’m researching more about “Content” roles.

elements.text:
How would you approach determining your position’s worth at your employer?

I was recently asked by my manager to “come up with a dollar amount” on the value of my position. I’m assured this isn’t some sideways test — we’re trying to come up with a budget for hiring additional content staff.

I’m a content director, running the content strategy process for a small SEO agency in California.

I’m happy with my salary, which is my reference point. But I’m researching more about “Content” roles.

text: start with a market rate search and your job description AND what you *actually* do.

text: Thank you all for your input. I’ll start here.

elements.text: Thank you all for your input. I’ll start here.

text: Thanks everyone for pitching in! The only issue I see with influencers is that as an agency providing mktg to small/midsize biz clients, there's no "industry" per se. Our clients span all industries, the only thing they have in common is that they are mostly regional businesses (and are looking to grow, obv). Our blog covers marketing topics, but the audience is business owners and decision makers, not marketing professionals (they might find it useful, but they won't become customers). Any thoughts around that and finding influencers?

elements.text: Thanks everyone for pitching in! The only issue I see with influencers is that as an agency providing mktg to small/midsize biz clients, there's no "industry" per se. Our clients span all industries, the only thing they have in common is that they are mostly regional businesses (and are looking to grow, obv). Our blog covers marketing topics, but the audience is business owners and decision makers, not marketing professionals (they might find it useful, but they won't become customers). Any thoughts around that and finding influencers?

text: Payscale is also a good research tool for salary info (yours or for people you’d hire)—I use this and Glassdoor as data points for hiring

text:
Hey Masooma! I think this article by <@U012UG9F6E8> will be helpful to you:

<https://marijanakay.com/blog/content-writer-feedback> I read it a few days back because I had trouble giving constructive feedback to the writers I work it. A lot of times, I want to make sure I give them the content brief and expect things only that's being mentioned in there. But if still there's a slight deviation, I provide examples and put out my point.

attachments.title: How to Give Clear, Actionable Feedback to Your Content Writers | Marijana Kay
attachments.text: Feedback you give to you writer should be straightforward and effortless for you and actionable for your writer. Here's how to achieve it.
attachments.fallback: Marijana Kay: How to Give Clear, Actionable Feedback to Your Content Writers | Marijana Kay
